thread.title: Mariners sail on, Windjammers shipwrecked in one-goal affairs
thread.title_full: Mariners sail on, Windjammers shipwrecked in one-goal affairs

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Mariners sail on, Windjammers shipwrecked in one-goal affairs
text:
Mariners sail on, Windjammers shipwrecked in one-goal affairs Mazurek, Stone tally goals for Oceanside By Staff | Sep 30, 2015 
The Oceanside and Camden Hills high school field hockey teams continue to jockey for position in the Maine Principals' Association Class B North standings with the end of the regular season — and the start of the playoffs — only a few weeks away. 
On Tuesday, Sept. 29, the Mariners made a mark in the win column with a 2-1 decision over Morse of Bath, while the Windjammers were dealt a 1-0 loss by Leavitt of Turner in a game halted midway through the second half due to rain. 
The following is a recap of reported results: 
Oceanside 2, Morse 1 
At Rockland Sept. 29, the Mariners got a pair of second-half goals and rallied to beat the Shipbuilders. Morse led 1-0 at halftime. 
Alexis Mazurek tied the game for Oceanside off a penalty corner with 6:44 left in regulation, while Michaela Wright scored the game-winner with 42 seconds remaining, off assists by Clara Feltus and Makayla VanBlarcom. 
Katie More scored in the first half for Morse. 
Oceanside held a 19-3 edge in shots and a 12-1 edge in penalty corners. 
Lauren Hoppe made two saves in the cage for Oceanside, while Madeline Baker made 16 saves in goal for Morse. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class B North, Oceanside (3-6-1, 16.8112 points) is 10th, while Foxcroft Academy of Dover-Foxcroft (10-0, 68.2143 points) is first in the 14-team region. The top 10 teams qualify for the playoffs. 
Leavitt 1, Camden Hills 0 
At Turner Sept. 29, the Hornets stung the Windjammers, prevailing by one goal. The game was called with 18:17 left in the second half due to rain. Games are 30-minute halves. 
"It sprinkled on and off during the first half,” said Camden Hills coach Lindsey Clement. “Soon after the second half started, it began to pour and the refs stopped the game. We waited about 15 minutes to see if the weather was going to let up, but it didn't. Thankfully the refs gave us another opportunity to start playing again, but by that time the field had standing water on it. Visibility was poor, and the ball would stop dead in the puddles so they called it early.” 
Allie Belaine scored the lone goal for Leavitt with seven minutes left in the first half. 
Camden Hills held a 5-3 lead in shots and a 6-2 edge in penalty corners. Jenna Stearns played in the cage for the Windjammers. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class B North, Camden Hills (6-3, 22.9592 points) is eighth, while Foxcroft Academy of Dover-Foxcroft (10-0, 68.2143 points) is first in the 14-team region. The top 10 teams qualify for the playoffs.
